Summary As a 5’4” female electrical engineer, I’m not exactly the quintessential construction project manager. But as construction has undergone a revolution to be more collaborative, lean, and productive, my quick learning and strong communication skills have enabled me to not only excel, but enjoy this fast-paced and challenging environment. In my almost 4 years at Intel, I have led and managed in various roles ranging from electrical engineer to design manager to continuous improvement task force lead. 
 
Working at CDM as an intern and part-time during college allowed insight into the consulting design world and emphasized a customer-centric focus. After graduating, I chose a career path in construction to gain a better understanding of the whole process, so that I could be more informed when making decisions. 
 
I'm truly passionate about my work and always eager to improve the status quo. The great people in construction motivate me every day to push myself, and while I enjoy tackling complex and ambiguous problems, my favorite part about projects is seeing a happy, satisfied team at the end. According to StrengthsFinders 2.0, I have the qualities of: Individualization, Connectedness, Input, Communication, and Maximizer. 
 
I have a dual BS from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Electrical and Electric Power Engineering, and graduated cum laude in 2011. 
 
I am looking forward to new opportunities to expand my knowledge and undertake exciting challenges. I drive to achieve and have fun while doing so, and believe that collaboration and alignment are key to success for any endeavor. Experience Life Safety Systems/Security Project Engineer Intel Corporation June 2014  –  July 2015  (1 year 2 months) Chandler, AZ Managed the initial design and estimation process for $26M in Life Safety System/Security scope for two international fab conversions.In current detailed design phase, review 2D drawings and 3D models, answer questions from the design builder, and complete gap analysis for layout releases. Details involve overseeing security for data center, placing gas detection equipment appropriately, and upgrading the fire alarm system. In addition, was chosen to write an article for Construction Users Roundtable’s national magazine The Voice concerning her perspective on the construction industry and the changes she anticipates. Construction Project Engineer Intel Corporation January 2014  –  June 2014  (6 months) Chandler, AZ Edwards Vacuum Pumps Task Force Lead and Commissioning Lead: Track and manage efficiency/productivity opportunities and any waste in Edwards’ scheduled activities. Follow up with stakeholders to improve the overall process and enable Edwards to complete the tool install ramp with half of the projected needed manpower. Compile commissioning indicators, present status weekly, and track down any open issues. Basebuild Design Manager Intel Corporation July 2013  –  January 2014  (7 months) Chandler, AZ Partnered with the design firm to enable a smooth close out of fab construction. Tasks included leading the DRTF, reviewing any 2B change orders, and resolving any hot issues concerning design. Created a new Lessons Learned Process based on Lean principles and completed the project's lessons learned in an efficient, meaningful manner. This process is currently being looked at to be used across Intel Construction. Electrical Discipline Lead Intel Corporation June 2012  –  January 2014  (1 year 8 months) Chandler, AZ Came to the fab construction project with $20M electrical budget in yet to buy and successfully managed associated scope while keeping to fast-paced schedule. Owned coordination of electrical design, construction, and into commissioning, while resolving any electrical questions. Champion of Basebuild Electrical Kaizen. Formed the team, charter, and mapped the process during a one-week event. The recommendations could ultimately reduce the time between design completion and construction completion by 7 months. Also developed the Pre-assignments Guidelines Handbook with the Site Infrastructure team locally and internationally. This involved key integration and agreement between multiple stakeholders. Created and maintained the electrical pre-assignments for the project. Tool Install Design Engineer Intel Corporation June 2011  –  June 2012  (1 year 1 month) Chandler, AZ Face of design to the customer for Tool Install and helped resolve any issues to enable Tool Install packages to be delivered to construction on time. Helped lead the implementation of the Kaizen Design Process, which reduced the design duration by 34% and the number of meetings by 50%. Created and delivered training to individual teams. Was also owner of breaker schedule maintenance which minimized the amount of times a panel was taken down to be populated by breakers to meet the Tool Install schedule. Electrical and Automation Services Intern CDM Smith May 2008  –  August 2010  (2 years 4 months) Designed and drafted (using AutoCAD) electrical and instrumentation aspects such as process and instrumentation diagrams, site plan layouts, lighting systems, motor schematics, and one-line diagrams for large-scale projects. Co-led electrical work for retrofitting a large wastewater treatment plant. Was responsible for coordinating this joint project with another engineering firm as well as arranging details with the project manager and other engineering disciplines. Received Quick Hit Award for proactively coordinating and resolving CAD issues within the office as well as for high levels of knowledge, commitment, and teamwork. Summary Originally trained as an engineer, I moved into human-centered design a dozen years ago based on experiences at MIT and Nokia Research. Since 2004, I have been advocating for (and doing) design as a process of systematic innovation to improve the positive impact we have on society. Most of my work during the last decade has been focused on design and innovation in health globally. 
 
Today I am a partner at Gobee Group, a firm that I co-founded in 2008 to carry this design agenda forward. I also teach design at UC Berkeley's School of Public Health. 
 
Since 2012 I have been an adviser to three international, technology-enabled social enterprises: 
• Juabar, Tanzania, franchise model for mobile phone recharging 
• Logistimo, India, mobile phone enabled supply chain management 
• Rivet, India, health care entrepreneurship accelerator 
 
My recent professional activities include: 
• Member, Funding Board, Alameda County Innovations in Reentry Program (2013) 
• Judge, United States Patent and Trademark Office (USPTO) Patents for Humanity competition (2012) 
• Member, Immunization Information Systems Working Group, Developing a Vision for Immunization Supply Systems in 2020, PATH & WHO with funding from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (2011) 
• Charter Member, U.S. National Language Service Corps, Mongolian (2010-present) 
• Member, Intrahealth OPEN Council, promoting open-source health applications for Africa, funding from USAID (2010-present) 
• Reviewer, California Management Review (2009-present) 
• Reviewer, Bulletin of the World Health Organization (2011-present) Summary Originally trained as an engineer, I moved into human-centered design a dozen years ago based on experiences at MIT and Nokia Research.
